unnormalised: AICTE has announced a new initiative to integrate LaTeX more deeply into engineering curricula across India. Starting next semester, select colleges will pilot programs requiring students to submit assignments using LaTeX for all maths and physics-related coursework. Seems like a big deal, eh?
normalised: A-I-C-T-E has announced a new initiative to integrate L-a-T-e-X more deeply into engineering curricula across India. Starting next semester, select colleges will pilot programs requiring students to submit assignments using L-a-T-e-X for all maths and physics-related coursework. Seems like a big deal, eh?

unnormalised: This move aims to improve the clarity and accuracy of mathematical notation in student work. No more squinting at badly-written equations! The decision came after a review panel found that many students struggled with representing complex equations properly, often resorting to handwritten submissions. Dr. Sharma from IIT Delhi, a member of the review panel, emphasized the importance of LaTeX for technical writing, stating "It's basically essential for anyone wanting to publish in a serious journal, or even just communicate effectively with peers." He even showed some examples: `\frac{1}{2}` clearly looks better than 1/2!

unnormalised: The pilot program will also include workshops for faculty to help them become proficient in LaTeX. Funding of up to Rs. 50,000 per institution will be provided to cover training and resource materials. Some students are already prepping, downloading editors like Texmaker and Overleaf. Looks like it's time to brush up on those backslash commands folks! The first report on this pilot programme is expected by 15/12/2024.
